data.title: Laurie Lewis and Tom Rozum Collection, 1972
data.text:
This collection has access restrictions. For details, please see the restrictions.

This collection has use restrictions. For details, please see the restrictions.

This is a finding aid. It is a description of archival material held in the Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Unless otherwise noted, the materials described below are physically available in our reading room, and not digitally available through the World Wide Web. See the Duplication Policy section for more information.

Archival processing of the audiovisual materials was made possible through a grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

Expand/collapse Collection Overview

Expand/collapse Information For Users

Expand/collapse Processing Information

Expand/collapse Subject Headings

Expand/collapse Related Collections

Expand/collapse Biographical Information

Laurie Lewis, a white bluegrass singer, songwriter, fiddler, bandleader, producer and record label owner, has released records for Rounder Records, Flying Fish, and her own record label, Spruce and Maple. She is a pioneering woman in bluegrass music and a frequent collaborator with Kathy Kallick, Linda Ronstandt, and Alice Gerrard. She is a two-time championship fiddler, IBMA award winner for Song of the Year "Who Will Watch the Homeplace" (1994) and Female Vocalist of the Year (1992, 1994) and Grammy nominee with Tom Rozum for Best Traditional Folk Album (1996). Lewis was also the director of Bluegrass Week workshop at the Augusta Heritage Center in Elkins, W.Va., for ten years (1986-1996). Tom Rozum is a white multi-instrumentalist, who primarily plays the mandolin, but also plays the fiddle, mandola, and guitar. He joined Laurie Lewis as part of the original Grant Street Band in 1986. A long-time fixture of the Bay-area music scene, Rozum is known for The Oak and the Laurel (1995), his Grammy-nominated album of duets with Laurie Lewis and his solo album Jubilee (1998).

Back to Top

Expand/collapse Scope and Content

The personal collection of Laurie Lewis, a white bluegrass singer, songwriter, fiddler, bandleader, producer and record label owner, and Tom Rozum, a white bluegrass musician. The collection contains audiovisual materials, photographic materials, computer discs, correspondence, promotional materials, festival files, scrapbooks, and ephemera related to Laurie Lewis and Tom Rozum's music career and published recordings, both as solo artists and as collaborators. Collection materials document the folk music, bluegrass music, and country music scenes of the United States from the 1970s to 2000s, with many materials documenting musicians, venues, and festivals in California and the west coast during this time. Photographs consist of photo albums, promotional portraits, contact sheets, snapshots, and 35mm photographic slides. Ephemera includes backstage passes, festival buttons, and a Grammy medallion, among other materials. Audio recordings include ADAT and open reel studio tapes, audiocassette recordings of live performances, and private issue releases compiled by Laurie Lewis and Tom Rozum, while video recordings consist mostly of music videos, television appearances, and performance footage of Laurie Lewis and Tom Rozum. Notable performers featured on these recordings include Sam Bush, Good Ol' Persons, Kathy Kallick, Patsy Montana, Charles Sawtelle, and Sam Bush.

The collection includes materials related to the following published recordings or albums: Laurie Lewis & Grant Street, Grant Street String Band (1983); Laurie Lewis, Restless Rambling Heart (1986); Laurie Lewis, True Stories (1993), Laurie Lewis & Tom Rozum, The Oak and the Laurel (1995), Laurie Lewis, Earth and Sky: Songs of Laurie Lewis (1997), Laurie Lewis, Seeing Things (1998), Laurie Lewis & Tom Rozum, Winterâ€™s Grace (1999), Laurie Lewis & Her Bluegrass Pals (1999), Tom Rozum, Jubilee (1998); and Charles Sawtelle, Music from Rancho DeVille (2001).
